III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Case worker gave caregiver permission to allow a 12-year-old
foster child to watch pornography.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 5/9/25. Complainant
stated that a TDM was held on 5/7/25 to discuss two other
children in the case. However, in the meeting, safety planning was
discussed regarding the return home of Youth with the other
children. The safety plan included cameras in the home, checking
the kids at night, children changing, and showering separately,
etc. Foster Care Worker then asked to add information that
Youth’s safety plan included information about viewing
pornography. Foster Care Worker said they told fictive kin it was
appropriate and normal, and Youth was allowed to view material
as long as no other child was in the room. TDM Facilitator asked
how old Youth was. Foster Care Worker answered that he was 12
years old. TDM Facilitator asked Foster Care Worker if she was
aware that someone had to be 18 years old to access
pornography. Foster Care Worker seemed surprised and stated
they did not know there was an age requirement. Parent stated
she did not support allowing Youth to watch sexual material.
Parent reported there would be parental controls at home to
prevent access. Parent stated she would have age-appropriate
conversations with Youth about his body, safety, consent, etc.
DHHS Worker stated Foster Care Worker needed to discuss this
issue and provide clarification to Foster Parent that pornography
was inappropriate. Foster Parent was not in attendance at the
meeting. Foster Care Worker did not respond initially, as she
seemed to be having trouble with her phone. After the meeting,
TDM Facilitator sent the meeting report and reiterated in an email
that the issue needed to be addressed with Foster Parent.
Complainant reported Foster Care Worker’s supervisor was
present for the start of the meeting but had to leave early and
missed the conversation regarding pornography.
2

Chief Administrator was notified of the investigation via email on
5/9/25. Chief Administrator responded she did not have first-hand
knowledge of the incident.
DHHS Worker was interviewed via video call on 5/9/25. DHHS
Worker confirmed she was at the TDM on 5/7/25. Foster Care
Worker did not say she or Foster Parent allowed Youth to watch
pornography. The discussion arose at the TDM as there was
concern about Youth trying to access pornography. This concern
was brought to the attention of Foster Care Worker, by Foster
Parent. The TDM discussion was to safety plan with the parents
as return home may be occurring soon. Foster Care Worker
stated Youth was curious about sex and tried to access
inappropriate material. Therefore, it was important for Parent to
speak with him about what is appropriate, and privacy with his
body, as there are younger children in the home. Foster Care
Worker attended the meeting by phone and had some difficulty
with her phone service. Therefore, some of what she said was
hard to understand and may have been misheard. TDM Facilitator
asked Foster Care Worker to restate what she said. Foster Care
Worker said she would speak with Foster Parent about it. TDM
Facilitator stated that someone needed to be 18 to access
pornography. Foster Care Worker stated that she was aware.
After the meeting, DHHS Worker spoke with Foster Care Worker.
It was clarified that Youth accessed inappropriate material, prior to
Foster Parent putting parental controls on their phone. Foster
Parent was not “letting” Youth access the material. Foster Care
Worker brought it up in the meeting in order to safety plan with
Parent for return home. Foster Care Worker wanted Parent to be
aware that Youth was attempting to sneak and watch things he
should not. Foster Care Worker did not give Youth or Foster
Parent permission for Youth to watch pornography. The worker
was trying to notify the group that a situation happened, and they
needed to continue to address it. DHHS Worker stated Foster
Care Worker maybe could have worded things better and also her
phone cutting out may have contributed to confusion about what
was being said.
Attempts were made to interview Parent on 5/27/25 and 5/29/25.
Two phone numbers were attempted, but both were not in
services.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video call on 5/29/25.
The allegation was read, and she stated it was incorrect. Foster
Care Worker said her words were twisted and that was not what
she said in the meeting. Foster Care Worker stated she told
3

Foster Parent that Youth’s curiosity was normal for that age, but
they needed to take precautions to stop him from watching
pornography. Foster Care Worker noted pornography was
everywhere, especially if Youth had access to social media.
Foster Care Worker told Youth and Foster Parent he should not
be accessing inappropriate material especially because there
were young children around; if he were to look at something it
should be in the privacy of his own room. Foster Care Worker was
asked if she could hear how that may sound like she was giving
him permission to watch inappropriate material as long as he was
in his room. Foster Care Worker stated she could see now that
someone might think that, but it was definitely not what she
meant. Foster Care Worker stated Youth had accessed
pornography before but had not tried to in a while. Regardless,
she brought up the topic to safety plan with the parents for return
home. Parent said she would put parental controls on tablet and
phones and ensure Youth did not watch anything inappropriate.
The plan was also to limit access to technology and put him in
extra activities to limit his free time. Foster Care Worker stated
there was conversation with Parent and Foster Parent about
removing technology and appropriate discipline if Youth attempted
to access pornography again. Foster Parent was never given
permission to allow Youth to watch inappropriate material. Foster
Care Worker stated that Licensing Supervisor was present for a
conversation regarding this.
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed by phone on 5/29/25.
Licensing Supervisor stated he went to the foster home on 5/12/25
with Foster Care Worker and spoke with Foster Parent about
Youth viewing inappropriate material online. Licensing Supervisor
also spoke with Youth, who stated he looked at pornography
previously, out of curiosity. Licensing Supervisor discussed
Youths behaviors with Foster Parent. The main concern was
destruction of the home and overeating. Youth had demonstrated
impulsivity and stated previously he did not know why he did the
things he did. It was determined a psychiatric evaluation would be
scheduled. Licensing Supervisor stated there had not been any
recent concerns about pornography that he was aware of.
However, there was a safety plan in place that Foster Parent and
Parent agreed to. The plan was to put parental locks on
technology around the house and to redirect Youth if he was
accessing anything he should not. Foster Parent was able to
monitor Youth’s technology usage in real time and check history if
there were concerns. This safety plan was discussed with Foster
Care Worker and Foster Parent during the visit. Licensing Worker
stated he had a conversation with Foster Care Worker after the
4

visit and it was clear she did not condone Youth’s behavior,
although it was not unusual for a youth of that age to be curious.
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone on 6/4/25. Foster Parent
was informed of the allegation and stated it was not accurate.
Foster Parent was not in attendance at the TDM on 5/7/25.
However, Foster Care Worker had never told her it was ok to
allow Youth to watch pornography. Youth had attempted to
access pornography and Foster Parent caught him. Foster Parent
reported this to Foster Care Worker and a safety plan was
developed. Foster Care Worker told Foster Parent that she
understood it was impossible to monitor Youth 24/7. However,
they could use parental controls to monitor online activity. They
should also ensure he was not alone with other youth, where he
could attempt to show them something inappropriate. Foster
Parent stated she was clear that it was not ok for Youth to watch
pornography, even if he was alone. Foster Care Worker never
gave caregiver or Youth “permission” to allow it.
Documents
• 5/8/25 email from TDM Facilitator to DHHS Worker and
Foster Care Worker: “Please address with (Youth’s) foster
mother that an adult cannot encourage a minor child to
view any pornography”.
• TDM report dated 5/7/25: Attendees: Parent, DHHS
Worker, Foster Care Worker. “The parents will talk to
(Youth) about the negativity of watching pornographic
material and discuss age-appropriate about sex and safe
touch/safe space”.
Analysis Based on interviews it does not appear Foster Care Worker gave
“permission” to Foster Parent for Youth to watch pornography. Per
Foster Parent, DHHS Worker, Licensing Supervisor, and Foster
Care Worker, the intent was to address a recent behavior and
provide a safety plan. However, the way in which Foster Care
Worker expressed this information was interpreted differently by
Complainant, who was not directly involved in the case.
CONSULTATION:
Foster Care Worker was cautioned to think about what she says
and how it may be heard by others.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
